text:
WOLF BLITZER: What message
does this send to our allies

for him to be making a claim
like this with no evidence

to back it up especially
in front of a world
leader like Angela Merkel?

REPRESENTATIVE JASON
CHAFFETZ: Well,

if the president has evidence, I
wish he would share it with us.

Now, the House
Intelligence Committee

is leading out on this
and looking into Russia.

But I can tell you
from the oversight

and government
reform perspective,

we haven't seen
evidence of this.

I haven't seen evidence
of mass voter fraud.

And I have not seen evidence of
wiretapping by President Obama.

So if there's something
there, we will reiterate,
please share it with us.
But we haven't seen it.

WOLF BLITZER: Your
Republican colleague,
Congressman Tom Cole--
you know him.

He said, today, that President
Trump owes President Obama

an apology for what he
called his reckless claim
on wiretapping.
Do you agree?

REPRESENTATIVE JASON
CHAFFETZ: Well, let's
get to the conclusion of it.

I mean, if the
president is still,

as recently as today, is
saying that he believes it's
true that, that extends it.

Again, we haven't come
to the conclusion.

And so, we'll let the facts
take us where they are.

But I haven't seen any
facts in this case.

I'd like them to
share them with us.

WOLF BLITZER: The White
House today also insisted,

that it offered no apology
to the British government

for accusing its
intelligence agency of spying

on the president at Trump
Tower during the campaign under
orders from President Obama.

The president and the
White House press secretary

were citing a report by
Judge Andrew Napolitano,
a Fox legal analyst.
Was that a mistake--

to utter those words from
the podium of the White House

and for the
president, once again,

to repeat that report
by Judge Napolitano?

REPRESENTATIVE JASON
CHAFFETZ: Well, I

hope that people understand that
just one account of one news

story, particularly
when some of these

are just by anonymous sources,
that's not nearly enough--

doesn't rise to the
level where you should
be out and repeating those.

They have to be very
careful that way.

I have not seen all the facts
in that particular issues.

So, I can't issue sort of
my final judgment on it.

But again they need
to be ultra careful.

The leader of the free world--
and when you're at that podium,

you've got to be very,
very careful with that.

WOLF BLITZER: Yeah, you
heard that statement

from Shepard Smith
on Fox News right

after the president made that
statement today at the news

conference, saying Fox has
no evidence at all to back up

the assertions from Judge
Napolitano or anything else

suggesting that the
president was wiretapped.

Here is the bottom
line question.

That I want to move
on, Congresswoman.

Why do you think the president
is reaching for a single Fox

News story to back up his
claims instead of relying

on the US intelligence
community or the law
enforcement community?

He's the President
of the United States.

He could just pick up the
phone and say, get over
here, tell me what's going on.

Instead he's relying
on these news reports.
Why do you think that is?

REPRESENTATIVE JASON
CHAFFETZ: I'm not
in a position to answer that.
I'm really not.
You have to ask the White House.

You have to ask the
president yourself.
I don't know.
